title: 105_hr2184
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Private Security Officer Quality Assurance Act of 1997". Congress recognizes the rapid growth of private security officers in the United States, who assist public law enforcement in crime prevention. The private security industry offers entry-level opportunities for job seekers, including those affected by economic challenges. These officers protect individuals and various properties such as banks, hospitals, airports, and schools, complementing the services provided by sworn law enforcement officers. Private security officers supplement sworn law enforcement officers in providing services to the public. The growth of private security in large shopping malls has increased public contact with security personnel. This trend has accelerated as the number of public sector law enforcement officers has decreased, serving public policy goals in combating serious crimes. Despite differences in duties, the public struggles to differentiate between private security and sworn law enforcement officers. Private security officers are essential in supplementing sworn law enforcement officers to combat serious crimes. The public has difficulty distinguishing between the two, leading to a demand for well-trained private security personnel. Screening for private security officers should be thorough, especially since many carry weapons. Private security officers play a crucial role in supporting law enforcement in fighting serious crimes. There is a need for well-trained private security personnel, especially since many are armed. Background checks for private security officers should be comprehensive. Private security officers must undergo background checks for identification and criminal history records. The Attorney General receives fingerprints from employers or associations, searches databases, and provides results within 30 days. The use of advanced technology is encouraged for compiling criminal history information. The Attorney General encourages the use of advanced technology for compiling criminal history information. Associations must submit employee fingerprints for identification within one business day and provide records to employers promptly. Associations also share information with licensing authorities and regulatory agencies. The Attorney General may establish regulations for security and confidentiality. The Attorney General may prescribe regulations for the security, confidentiality, accuracy, use, and dissemination of information transferred to employers. A report on inquiries made by employers must be submitted to the Senate and House Committees on the Judiciary 2 years after the enactment of the bill. SEC. 4. CONFORMING AMENDMENTS.

Subsection (d) of section 534 of title 28, United States Code, is amended to include an association of employers of private security officers designated by the Attorney General for conducting background checks.

SEC. 5. CRIMINAL PENALTY.

Using information obtained under section 3 for purposes other than determining suitability for employment as a private security officer can result in a fine of up to $50,000 or imprisonment for up to two years.

SEC. 6. EMPLOYER LIABILITY.

Employers relying on criminal history information provided by the Attorney General for employment decisions are protected from liability in any damages action.

SEC. 7. DEFINITIONS. The Act defines key terms such as "Attorney General," "employee," "employer," "fingerprint," and "private security officer." It clarifies that an employer includes those providing security services as independent contractors and individuals licensed or certified by states. The Act defines a private security officer as an individual who performs security services for consideration, whether armed or unarmed, but excludes sworn police officers, licensed professionals, internal auditors, military personnel, and certain other individuals. The Act defines private security officers as individuals who perform security services, including observation, reporting, deterrence of theft, protection of individuals or property, and more. Excluded are sworn police officers, licensed professionals, internal auditors, and military personnel. Private security officers perform a variety of security services, including protecting individuals or property, controlling access to premises, maintaining order at public activities, and providing canine services for detecting unlawful substances. The term "State" refers to several regions including states, territories, and commonwealths. The Attorney General can charge a user fee for obtaining an individual's criminal history information. The effective date of this Act is July 1, 1999.
